H0.text: Earth rotates on its axis, which explains how day and night occur in different parts of Earth.

H1.text: Earth revolves around the Sun explains how day and night occur in different parts of Earth.

H2.text: The Sun rotating on its axis explains how day and night occur in different parts of Earth.

H3.text: The Sun revolving around the galaxy explains how day and night occur in different parts of Earth.

A4.text: Earth rotates once in about 24 hours with respect to the Sun, but once every 23 hours, 56 minutes and 4 seconds with respect to other distant stars (see below).

A5.text: Earth's rotation period relative to the International Celestial Reference Frame, called its stellar day by the International Earth Rotation and Reference Systems Service (IERS), is 86 164.098 903 691 seconds of mean solar time (UT1) (23h 56m 4.098903691s, 0.99726966323716 mean solar days).
